awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A flexible learning and assessment tool based on a skill mastery approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will serve the national interest by improving the ability of universities to train a globally competitive STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) workforce. The core technology in this project provides students with the opportunity to practice questions in a personalized environment until mastery is achieved.  The technology also makes it easy for instructors to incorporate frequent and second chance testing while scaling to support more students. These pedagogical strategies have been shown to reduce the failure rates in STEM classes and could disproportionately benefit women, minorities, first-generation students, and students of low socio-economic status. Helping these students can improve retention efforts, in general, and for diverse students, in particular. The commercial potential of this project includes capturing a significant fraction of the rapidly-growing university education technology market with potential markets worldwide as well as in non-university education sectors.

This I-Corps project aims to develop a Software as a Service (SaaS) online platform for creating and delivering learning experiences and assessments for students, with a focus on university-level STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) courses. The platform allows instructors to easily combine adaptive, rule-based and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to generate and grade different randomized versions of activities and assessments. It includes novel AI auto-grading algorithms for complex question types including symbolic mathematics, interactive student drawing, live coding, and natural language input. The core algorithms advance the state of the art in three key ways: (1) The use of AI auto-grading can entirely eliminate the use of human graders in university courses, dramatically reducing staffing levels and costs, and enabling expansion to larger and more diverse student populations; (2) The platform deters cheating with a set of novel algorithms; and (3) The platform uses sophisticated grading algorithms that incentivize mastery learning and that lead to substantial improvements in learning outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois

por.por_cntn:
PrairieLearn is an online platform for creating and delivering learning experiences and assessments for students, with a focus on university-level STEM (Science, Tech, Engineering, Math) courses. It allows instructors to easily combine adaptive rule-based and AI algorithms to generate and grade different randomized versions of activities and assessments. PrairieLearn includes novel AI auto-grading algorithms for complex question types including symbolic mathematics, interactive student drawing, live coding, and natural language input. 

During this project, we conducted over 150 customer interviews, which played a crucial role in creating a business model for PrairieLearn Inc. Based on our findings, we decided to focus on addressing the STEM higher education programs in North America. Moreover, based on knowledge obtained during customer interviews, we achieved the following outcomes:

  • implementation of a student-pay model to supplement contracts with universities

  • development of single-sign-on and LTI 1.3 

  • development of a mechanism to share questions to facilitate onboarding, and the creation of a website for Open Educational Resources

  • received an NSF/SBIR award to develop a non-code graphical interface where PrairieLearn users can create questions without needing to use code, allowing us to reach a much broader market.

 

The core technology of PrairieLearn and the commercial offering of the hosted service has the potential to impact the Higher Education STEM Technology Market, evaluated at $27 billion in 2020. Teaching pedagogies have changed drastically over the last few years, especially since the COVID 19 pandemic and the wide availability of Large Language Models, pressuring instructors to become more creative on how to use online teaching tools. The need for better teaching and assessment tools is not going away now that classes are back to in-person mode. Indeed, instructors and administrators are aware that going back to traditional ways of providing course content and measuring learning goals is no longer the best solution to our current generation of students. PrairieLearn provides students with the opportunity to practice questions in a personalized environment until mastery is achieved, and makes it easy for instructors to incorporate frequent and second chance testing while scaling to support more students. These pedagogical strategies have been shown to reduce the failure rates in STEM classes that could disproportionately benefit women, minorities, first-generation students, and students of low socioeconomic status. Helping these students can improve retention efforts, in general, and for diverse students in particular, increasing national competitiveness in STEM.

 This project aims to serve the national interest by improving the ability of American universities to train a globally competitive STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) workforce in the United States. The health of this workforce is vital to America’s economic prosperity, our scientific and technological competitiveness, and our national security.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2024
Modified by: Mariana T Silva
